div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7239] ALEXANDRIA, THURSDAY, JULY 13, 1905. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.
Berths can be definitely engaged as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibraltar, Plymouth and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passenegers to the ship.

The Brindial Express Steamer leaves Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passenegrs can go on board the evening before. The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arrivnig in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is €22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
the Sea fares are:
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marseilles.
TO THE EAST

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Aden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcutta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passenegers can embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: FAST BRITISH PASSENGER STEAMERS
GREECE - TURKEY LINE.
Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.
PALESTINE - SYRIA LINE.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).
RED SEA LINE.

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency. 31-12-904

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste.

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday a.m. in time for express to Paris, London, Naples, Rome. Arrival Trieste Wednesday noon connecting with Vienna Express (Trieste-Ostende through carriage) and expresses to Italy and Germany.
Fortnightly Service: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste
Steamers leaves Alexandria on or about 11 and 25 October

(Departures from Suez) To Aden, Bombay, Colombo, Penang, Singapore, Hong-Kong, Shanghai, Yokohama, Kobé about October 5 and Nov. 4. To Aden and Bombay accelerated service about October 9 and November 9. To Aden, Karachi, Bombay, Colombo, Madras, Rangoon, and Calcutta about October 20.

div.head: INTERNATIONAL SLEEPING AND RESTAURANT CARS COMPANY.

row.cell: Restaurant Car runs every day between Cairo & Alexandria & vice-versa.

div.p: By the 10.15 p.m. train between Cairo and Alexandria and vice-versa a sleeping car is attached every night. Supplement 30 P.T.

row.cell: Daily Restaurant Car Service between Cairo, Ismailia, Port Said & vice-versa.

div.p: Restaurant and Sleeping Cars on Luxor trains:
A Restaurant car and a sleeping car are attached to the 8 p.m. train from Cairo every Monday, Wednesday and Saturday and to the 5.30 p.m. train from Luxor every Tuesday, Thursday and Sunday.

Railway and Sleeping Car tickets can be obtained any number of days ahead at the office of the International Sleeping Car Company in Cairo Station. 1st class Cairo-Luxor P.T. 200. Sleeping Car supplement P.T. 75.
Mail delivered Khartoum, Sun. and Wednesday evening, and Cairo, Mon. and Friday evening. *Dining and Sleeping Cars.

La National Bank of Egypt reçoit des dépots à termes fixes, fait des avances et ouvre des comptes courants sur titres, valeurs et marchandises. Elle s’occupe de l’achat et de la vente d'effets sur l’Etranger, de l'escompte, ainsi que de toutes opérations de Banque. 31-12-904

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
Subscribed Capital JS1.500,000
Reserve Fund... 500,000
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

div.head: Hall's Sanitary Washable Distemper
div.p: Made in 70 Colors
An artistic wall covering.
This celebrated water paint is made in two qualities for Inside and Outside work

HALL’S SANITARY WASHABLE DISTEMPER is rapidly superseding wall papers in all tastefully furnished homes. It is made in 70 artistic tints, and only requires the addition of water to make it ready for use. It is quickly and easily applied with a whitewash brush, with half the labour and at one third the cost of paint. HALL’S DISTEMPER ensures cleanliness, and is pleasing to the eye. It appeals alike to artistic and practical house decoration. HALL’S DISTEMPER is of special value in hot climates. Owing to its cool, pleasing colours, great weather-resisting and germ-destroying properties, it lends itself to every kind of wall, wood, brick or stone coating, possessing all the advantages of paint, colour- wash, and disinfectant at one third the cost of oil paint. It never blisters in the hottest sun, and the fact that it can be washed adds greatly to its sanitary advantages.
Supplied in Tins and Iron Kegs.
Sole Manufacturers :
SISSONS BROTHERS & Co., Ltd., HULL.
Stocks are held In Cairo by FRANK RATCLIFFE, Sanitary Contractor and Engineer, Sharia Saptieh.
In Alexandria by RAMADAN YOUSSEF, Sanitary Contractor, Rue Sesostris.
General Agents: GEORGE MORRIS & Co.. Alexandria & Cairo.

div.head: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 24, 1905.
SPAIN AND FRANCE
div.p: The safe arrival of M. Loubet at Madrid and his enthusiastic reception by the Madri- lenos, will be delight those many Frenchmen and Spaniards to whom a Latin League, or, at all events, a close reapprochment between the Latin nations, is a polticial ideal. THe rela- tions between France and Spain are now thoroughly friendly, and French capital, al- ready interested more than that of any other nation in the development of the Iberian Kingdom, is more and more inclined to aid the development of Spanish industry. Since the Spanish-Smerican war, which proved nothing short of a blessing to Spanish Finance, the various political parties of Spain have all been inclined to adopt a policy of economy and retrenchment, and no Spanish Minister who proposed, say, a forward policy in Morocco or an ambitious programme of new naval construction, would have much chance of support. Spain requires years of recuperation before she can again play a great part in the councils of the Powers. The question of land tenure and the tension be- tween the Clerical and the Liberal elements have to be settled. Spanish Agriculure, which may have a great future, requires the inagura- tion of an extensive programme of irrigation works; the great mineral resources of the country are only half developed, and new industries must be built up to replace those ruined by the loss of the Phillippines, Cuba, and Porto Rico. For these objects, internal and external peace and the assitance of foreign capital and required, and Spain has no ambi- tion to make history for a generation to come.

The geographical situation of Spain-indeed of the whole Iberian Peninsula- is such that a friendly understanding with the kingdoms of Spain and Portugal is of vital importance both to France and to England. A hostile Spain would to some extent neutralise Gibraltar, since vessels lying in the docks could be easily reached by the long-range howitzers and siege guns from Algesiras. A hostile cruiser or two using the Spanish ports of Ferrol and Vigo or the Canaries as its base might do an infinity of damage to the merchant shipping, and if Spain's friendship is valuable to England it is precious to France, which has a southern land frontier to defend and would suffer fro the use of Port Mahon as a hostile base. Though navally impotent for the present, Spain, by the mere fact of her position, might conceivably turn the scale in a naval war, and the fact that both France and England realise the importance of doing their utmost to arrive at a friendly understanding with the monarchy of King Alfonso XIII., is of good augury for the world's peace. England has by her support to Spain's Moroccean aspirations, which, though not exten- sive, are still important, done something to atine for her unnecessarily anti-Spanish atti- tude in the Spanish-American conflict; a determination to keep the ring clear was natural enough, but our sympathy need not have taken a form that wounded Spanish pride.

div.head: LA COMMISSION DES LOCATAIRES
div.p: Nous avons reçu d’antres lettres à propos de la Commission des Locataires, mais il nous est impossible de continuer à insérer cette correspondance, là, polémique étant sortie du domaine public pour entrer dans le domaine privé. Nous regrettons que M. Mignot ait le premier employé des termes d’une violence exagérée' contre M. A. G. et que celui-oi se soit à son tour laissé entraîner contre M. Mignot à des insinuations qne nons considérons comme sans fondement aucun et qn’il regrette d’avrir laissé échapper dans la chalenr de la polém - que. (N.D.L.R.)
INFORMATIONS FINANCIERES

La question de l’intérêt de l’argent est à l’ordre dn jonr aussi bien en Egypte qn’cn Europe. Les journaux européens arrivés par le tout dernier oonrrier réflètent la préoccnpation qne leur donne cette question et expriment des craintes pour l’avenir.

Le marohé de Paris n’a pas en une meilleure allure la semaine passée qne la précédente. Ce n’est pas qne la cote ait été faible, mais il semble qne les dispositions si franchement con- fiantes dé naguère se soient qnelqne pen mo- difiées. Les r^KÜsations se sont poursnivies et ont presque ' constamment pesé snr les cours. An premier rang des préoccupations delà Bourse, se trouve la question de l’intérêt de l’argent On s’attendait, pendant les premières séances, à voir la Banque d’Angleterre procéder à une nouvelle augmentation du taux de l’escompte.

Ces craintes ne se Bont pas réalisées. Le taux de l’escompte n’a pas été augmenté à Londres la semaine passée, mais il pourra l’être la semaine prochaine, et cette appréhension para- ‘ lyse toute action nouvelle.

L’argent sera-t-il pins cher à la fin qu’su commencement du mois 1 On parait oroire à. des reports nn pen plus tendas, et l’on envi- sage oet enchérissement, comme une indication pour l’avenir. S’il en était ainsi, les positions jusqu’ici reportées pourraient donner lieu à des ventes assez suivies. Enfin, les questions ré- trospectives de politique extérieure, discutées dans la presse européenne, ont oréé un malaise contre lequel là Bourse n’a pas facilement réagi. Ou rie pense pas cependant qu’aucnn . incident sérieux puisse sortir de cette discus- sion tumultueuse.

Notons par oontre qne le comptant ne s’est guère laissé émouvoir par ces incidents : il a été sans doute moins actif qne précédemment, gardant ses disponibilités en vue des diffé rentes émissions annoncées, mais il ne s’est pa3 montré disposé à vendre les titres qu’il a jusqu’ici àbrerbés

En Egypte, dit le “Progrès,” le Banques en grande partie refusent d’ouvrir de nouveaux comptes d’avances sut titres et certaines mémo tirent la oorde à leurs clients en leur élevant le taux d’intérêts ou bien en leur limitant lerfr crédit.

Ge procédé de Banques, qui réservent leur dépôt pour l’aohat du change de la saison ootonnière actuelle, est la cause prinoipale de oette espèoe de orise ' financière qu’aggrave oette aimée davantage le renchérissement d’ar- gent octaepnné par les nouveaux emprunts russe et japonais et autres sur le marohé do Londres.

Dautre part, le nombre des valeurs, qui en valussent notre marohé, s’accroît de jour en jour au point de provoquerlun commencement de défiance. Mais en Bgy$â)on gobe tout et on restç impassible lorsque même on se voit littéralement volé, et pomme preuve vous aurez le résultat de la déb & ole de la société générale des Sucreries et Raffinerie. d’Egypte contre la quelle personne ne fera h moindre démarohe, si oen’est le groupe de défpasè des actionnaires Français. Qu’a-t-on fait contre les fondateurs de là Banque Industrielle d’Egypte, qui ont seuls profité de sa fondation, et de .la facilité avec laquelle ona zuinélapetite épargne! Rien. Il n’y a dono aucun espoiçhip voir le conseil d’administration et les direoreurs des Suoreries et Raffinerie d’Egypte, rendus responsables de lenr inqualifiable gestion, si la poussée ne venait de l’Europe.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
(Apj mr d’hui à midi ei fomifi)
div.p: La baisse va toujours en s’aocontnant et les affaires sont toujours excessivement clair- semées.

L’Agricole fléchit de 9 5/16 à 9 1/4, la Banque d’-Atbènes de 135 3/4 à 135 1/2, la Laud Bank de 9 5/8 à 9 9/16, la Daïra dn 17 13/16 à 17 5/8, l’Union Fonoière de 6/8 à 6 7/16, la Nungovich de 1013/16 à 10 3/4, la Menzàleh de 5 14 15/16, l’Alexandrie Water de 14 15/16 à 14 7/8, lés Eaux du Caire de 1130 à 1120.
Et les petites valeurs ne sont pas plus favo- risées : l’Investment tombe de 1 9/32 à 1 1/4, les Markets de 26 à 25/9, la Sait & Soda do 32/9 à 32/6.
Par contre, quelques titres sont mieux tenus: De ce nombre sont la Filature qui hausse do 13/16 à 7/8, la Khédivial Mail Privilégiée do 4 3/16 à 4 1/4 et les Privilégiées Tramways de 162 à 163.
Les Estâtes sont également plus fermes à 1 5/32.

L’émission des 100,000 notions de la Banquo d'Abyssinie aura lieu simultanément à Rome, à Paris et en Egypte, le 7 novembre. Les^ notions qui sont de 6 livres chaoune, seront' au prix de 7 livres. Il i\’y aura ni parts de fondateurs ni notions privilégiées. MM. McGillivray et M»roiano ont été nommé:' respectivement directeur et ofaef comptable de la nouvelle Banque. Toutes les autres non rsOae publiées au sujet dé là dite Banque sont prematures.
